headline: Beef Pot Roast
description: Make chuck roast in the oven with this easy, one-pot recipe for the ultimate melt-in-your-mouth pot roast that cooks for 2 hours until fork-tender.

video.description: This delicious pot roast is best made a day before serving.
video.name: Beef Pot Roast

name: Beef Pot Roast

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C).

Heat a Dutch oven or heavy pot over medium-high heat. Add oil, then sear meat in the center of the pan for 4 minutes. Turn meat over with tongs; sear for 3 to 4 minutes on each side. Remove meat from the pot.
Arrange onion, garlic, and 1 bay leaf in the bottom of the pan; sprinkle with salt and pepper. Return meat to the pan, place remaining bay leaf on top of meat, and cover.

Cook in the preheated oven for 30 minutes. Reduce heat to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C) and continue cooking until tender, about 1 1/2 hours. An instant-read thermometer inserted in the thickest part of the roast should read 145 degrees F (65 degrees C).
Transfer roast to a platter and let rest for 10 to 15 minutes. Slice and top with onions and gravy.

review.reviewBody: I have made this several times. It works great. I modify it for my needs - 3 Jalapeno peppers, Bell pepper and carrots. Plus other spices. 3 lb roast gives me 3 meals. :-)

Great recipe--used ~2lb USDA Choice chuck roast from costco, and generously salted/peppered the meat and let it sit overnight in the fridge prior to cooking for dinner the next day. Seared in a cast iron pan, and then transferred to a covered, 1.75 qt oven-safe ceramic sauce pot since I didn't have a Dutch oven. Followed the recipe exactly, and was pleasantly surprised how tender, juicy, and flavorful this recipe was. The surprisingly amount of juices generated from cooking the meat made a wonderful sauce with the onions/garlic/bayleaf mixture. Thank you very much!!

If I could rate this a zero I would. As being advertised as “the easiest recipe for a great pot roast”, this recipe lived up to an absolute zero of our expectations. Not only did we let our pot roast cook for extra amount of time, but we ended up covering it, WHICH THE RECIPE NEVER STATED TO DO. The hostality stated in these comments as well were uncalled for. The title of this recipe is easy pot roast, do you think experienced cooks are following this recipe??NO. This recipe is misleading, a waste of time, and a waste of money. I hope you have a better day because this recipe did not make mine better. As I am still waiting for my pot roast to be done after starting this recipe a total of four hours ago.

Works well. Those who did not cover the pot: that is on you, not the recipe. Use a good Dutch oven and it will turn out wonderfully. We make this dish monthly, with the only difference being adding a half-cup of liquid (broth, bone broth, blood from the roast + water) after browning. You can try other spices on the roast, too. It is a favorite!

I followed the instructions and the onions are sending fumes out of the kitchen into the Living Room. It's making my eyes water as well as my mouth. If I don't char it , it should be 5 stars good. Carrots are done in the microwave and taters on the stovetop. Keeping it simple

I always forget if I need to cover the roast or not. This was the first recipe on the section for Beef Pot Roast. I followed this recipe to the letter then added some potatoes sliced into wedges and carrots for the last hour or so. It came out perfect! So succulent and BEEFY, yum yum! It made fabulous gravy with the pan drippings, too. Thank you for this simple recipe, I'll do it like this from now on!!
Very good, finally achieved cooking a moist roast! Highly recommend adding some liquid (beef broth) to pot.

This was a really easy recipe and I really wanted to like it. I followed the recipe exactly, including the advice in the ratings to keep the pot tightly covered. It came out tough and dry. I am going to be unsaving this recipe and trying out another.
this was dry and not very tender. The bay leaf seemed to overwhelm this recipe. It was just ok. I would not make it again
Thought it would be dry but it wasn’t

Superb!!..Follow the instructions and it will turn out great....DO NOT ADD LIQUID as other commenters have stated...I only review the actual recipe.....You could deglaze the pan with wine or both and make a sauce after the meat is done...
Absolutely fantastic..
followed exactly and it came out soooooo overdone. had to drown in gravy just to eat it.

The recipe is amazing and I have been making it for years with electric and gas ovens. The trick is to cook until soft. If you over sear the meat the outside will have a crunchy crust. If you want completely soft then do not over sear. Your choice, cook dry though and do not add veggies and it will interfere with softness of the meat. The dry breaks down the sinew. Finally if onions and garlic burn, it’s ok add red wine and sugar the strain sauce, will be like a fine restaurants sauce, but strain. It will also clean your post. Born Apetit!
Made as is And it was real tasty

I was looking for a different way to cook a pot roast, something faster than my usual slow cook method in beef stock. This recipe was very easy and half the time of my usual recipe. I was, however, leery that it would not have enough flavor. The cooking method plus the simple ingredients created an easy, faster pot roast option. My husband is avoiding carbs so I made the gravy with a dollop of butter and full cream. I will make this again.

The flavor was so good. I had a 2.5lb grass-fed roast and it was a bit over cooked even though I took it out at 45 mins (vs. 1 1/2 hours). I will definitely cook this again as is, I’ll just check it sooner.
This was my 1st time ever cooking a pot roast! It was so delicious. I added additional seasonings and some green peppers with the onions. DELICIOUS!!!
Easy to follow and worked well for me.
this is the bomb soooo good and easy

Fabulous! So easy and delicious! Followed the recipe exactly, did not change a thing. I removed the chopped onions before making the gravy to give it a smoother consistency. Will make again and again and again! Thank you for sharing this recipe!

Super easy and very close to my 3 generation family recipe. I add cupped celery and parsley and double the garlic. And several dashes of Worcestershire sauce Brown all sides. Roast for 1 hour at 325 then add the carrots and potatoes and taste for 2 more hours at 300. Turns out incredible very time.
This is one of the best roast dish I have made. Easy and quick.
Followed the steps, added seasoning after searing and before placing in overnight and it turned out perfect! Very easy !!
I had only a little over 2 pounds so I halfed the recipe and cooked maybe an hour total and it came out excellent. Even my picky eaters loved it! Will be making again.
I followed this recipe exactly and it was perfect. Tender and such flavor! The gravy was especially tender. Perfect Sunday dinner!

Excellent results. Very tender beef (Chuck Roast). 
Modifications: I added sliced mushrooms; reset oven to 275 instead of 300. Poured Lipton Onion Soup mix over Roast before baking.
Easy to fix, meat was very tender and the flavor is great
It was Amazing!!!
I left out one bay leaf, but it was still amazing!
Was very good. Moist & will make it again.
This was probably entirely my fault but I believe I cooked it too long. I will try again.

Next time I will set oven at 300 degrees and leave it there. It did come out very tender and my family enjoyed it very much
Followed the recipe exactly. 4 out of 4 happy eaters!
I followed the recipe exactly and for the first time ever I cooked a successful pot roast! Used the stock in the bottom of the pot to make gravy and it was all delicious!

We love this easy simple recipe. Followed directions as written except we simmered this on the stove in our covered cast iron dutch oven for 4 hours on a lazy cold winters day. ( Without peeking of course! ) Second time using this recipe. Perfection!

Made this recipe tonight, I added a lot more garlic and added water to the bottom (maybe 2 cups? It was fantastic!! I misjudged and overcooked it but the meat was still moist and tender. The onions in the bottom were caramelized perfectly and I ended up just mashing them into the juices and thickened it with a flour/water slurry. Best. Gravy. Ever!! Will definitly use this recipe again.
This was excellent! Made it as written. I mixed the onions and drippings with a jar of beef gravy to make an au jus. Delicious!

I will definitely make this one again. I did season the roast with freshly ground salt, pepper and Costco granulated garlic prior to searing it, but that was the only thing I did that wasn't in the recipe. My boyfriend raved about the roast and made sure I didn't lose the recipe!

As was stated elsewhere, do not vary from this menu. Do not add potatoes, carrots, or stock. The moisture comes from the meat itself (and the onions). Prepare your vegetables separately - starting them during the 300F phase, i did them in the same oven, and the results could not have been better.
Made it exactly as stated. Delicious!

Wow! I'd give this 10 stars if I could. I was hesitant about this recipe because of some of the negative reviews saying it comes out dry, but I'm SO glad I decided to try it. I wanted something other than the typical slow cooker, onion soup mix, can of cream of mushroom recipe and this definitely delivered! Only change I made was doubling the garlic because we love garlic. This one is Absolutely a keeper. We can't wait to slice it and use the leftovers for sandwiches. Thank you for sharing this. Sincerely, Thank You!
Made no changes. Pretty tasty. Bay leave was not overpowering but came through as just a hint. Will make again.

I kept the recipe as is with only adding our preference of seasoning, OMG... we are not big red meat eaters but this was so tender and flavorful in its own juices (remember do your own thing on the seasoning part) that I will be making it again. DO NOT add water or broth to make gravy until the roast is done!
I was really happy with the way this turned out. This was my best pot roast ever and I followed the directions exactly.

This recipe turned out great! We added 4 cups of broth plus 1/4 cup red wine because we live in Colorado where it is very dry and foods need liquids to keep from drying out. The next time, we’ll use a little less liquid because it was so much. We seared the roast as recommended and then removed it from the Dutch Oven. We boiled the broth and then poured it into Dutch Oven to deglaze the bottom and get up the brown bits and added the wine. We put the roast back in and set the onion quarters around it. For an almost 5 lb. roast, it was done in 2 hours (145 degrees), but we had to keep it warm because the rest of the meal wasn’t ready yet and it got up to 160 degrees internal when we finally cut into it. But still the tastiest roast we had made. The gravy came out great as well with lots of liquid to work with.

Make this recipe exactly how it is stated. Don't get creative. Don't add Don't subtract. I make this, and it turns out tender and juicy and perfect every time. I like carrots and potatoes, so I make them in a separate dish and bake them alongside the roast.
I made this exactly as the recipe stated. It had an amazing flavor, was very tender and the best roast I have ever made. This one is a keeper!
Very good for an uncomplicated and low prep time pot roast. I made it exactly as stated in the morning before work, reheated later, and it was very tasty. Thanks!
Great nourishing easy comfort dish to make the cooler months.

I made it exactly as it stated and didn’t change a single thing,ughh, I check the meat when it was 160° it wasn’t tender at all, then I check when it was 170° it wasn’t tender too... I wait until the meat came up to the 180° same thing. I hate to throw it out but I have to.
LOVE Love it!!!
Great. Will make again with 1/2 onion, did add worcestershire, thanks for the tip.

This may be the best pot roast I have EVER tasted. Thanks to the other reviewers, I stayed true to the recipe even though I wanted to add potatoes and carrots. I made sure to give the meat a good sear. I am only cooking for two, so I used a 2 lb. boneless chuck roast. Being that small, I checked it an hour after I lowered the heat. It was already done. I let it rest 15 minutes. I think cooking the vegetables on the side made the difference. Plus the gravy right out of the pan on mashed potatoes was superb.

i made it it was one of the best i ever made......after i salted and peppered the meat then seared it. cut up onions lots of garlic and half a green pepper and 2 bay leaves and put them in. put in 1 1/2 packet of sazon on top of that and put the meat back in. then finally put 3 meat bouillon cubes in about 1 1/2 cup of boiling water then poured that on top. mistakenly cooked it at 375 for 30 mins then 300 for 1 1/2 hour. best one i have ever made wow.
Super simple and easy to make. I added a splash of red wine for some additional flavor; not sure how much of a difference it made, though.
Made exactly to the recipe. Roasted,in my deep cast iron skillet. Excellent flavorful, strained the onions and made a gravy, full of flavor, loved the hint of bay

I made this as written, except for adding a little more chopped onion. It came out perfectly, tender and delicious with plenty of gravy! While the roast was cooking I sautéed sliced mushrooms in butter and put them aside. After removing the cooked meat to the cutting board, I added the mushrooms to the onion gravy in the pan. Delicious! Thank you for the great recipe!
Tender . . . flavorful . . . a resounding success!
Prepare esta receta y quedo deliciosa.. además que es muy fácil..

I followed the recipe exactly except after 1 hour at 325 degrees, I lowered the oven to 300 degrees for 2 more hours. Adding the carrots and potatoes with a hour to go. I was happy with the amount of juices which made a wonderful gravy. The roast was moist and tender. This recipe is a keeper.
wonder recipe, the only thing I did different was add mushrooms
Delish!!!

So I read this and decided to skip a bunch of steps, essentially putting a half-thawed roast into my enamel Dutch oven, coat it with seasoning of your preference, and put a layer of onion and a sliced carrot in the botoom.

Great roast. Easy to make and comes out tasting great.

I followed this exactly using a 3.5 pound Blade Roast (I'm from Canada) that we got in our purchase of a 1/4 cow. I know some people said to put in broth and other things, but this recipe is perfect as is. I wanted a pot roast recipe that didn't taste like fat soaked vegetables. Used a dutch oven with a heavy lid and that keeps all the moisture in. The onion really helps keeps everything moist as well. I cooked this the day before so I was able to slice the meat very thin the next day. After cooking, I removed the onions, put them into a strainer to let the juices drain and then just reheated them the next day. I let the juices cool overnight in the fridge and scraped the fat off. Using some of the fat and the left over juices, I made a pan gravy with some homemade stock. Served everything with the leftover onions and some roasted potatoes and a veg. I would make this recipe over and over again.
Simple, straightforward, and FULL of flavor! We all enjoyed it, no leftovers! ??
I would definitely make this again. In fact, we are looking forward to it. Didn't change a thing and came out perfect.

Followed the recipe to a tee. Excellent ! It made its own juice, so no beef broth needed . Putting tinfoil tightly around my pot then the lid really helped. I had lots of leftovers and this morning chopped everything up and added a jar of marinara with some Italian seasonings . Placed in to two separate containers for the freezer for future dinners.

I seared it 1st. Added garlic n red pepper flakes along with pork rub seasoning. Bake 300 foil covered 2 hrs.tasted great but might have even cooked a little longer. Next time 1hr 45 mins. Shredded into burrito wraps with peppers and onions avocado salsa n cheese. Yummy served with rice

This dish was great. I seasoned the roast with salt, pepper and oregano and wrapped it up in plastic wrap. Tucked it in the fridge for 24 hours. Brought out roast today and let it sit for a half hour. Then followed the recipe to the letter. For gravy, I added some red wine to the simmering drippings along with a little beef bullion then added the roux. Made for a wonderful gravy. Meat was excellent. Recipe was simple and delicious. Will do again. Going bigger roast next time, it was that good.

This was delicious, I added carrots and cubed potatoes. The beef was so tender. ( Don't leave out the searing step) Will definitely make again. Already in my recipe rotation!!

Excellent! Will make again.

Delicious!! Pot roast in the oven definitely low and slow is best. Just felt this needed some liquid so half way through the recipe I changed it. I will post a different recipe with the changes I made as my family devoured it!
This was perfection. The onion gave off so much liquid, I was shocked. However it did not taste oniony. I was all out of bay leaves but it still came out great. What an easy and perfect recipe.

(Don’t even THINK of adding liquid!)
A very simple recipe with outstanding results!..melt in your mouth roast!!..will definitely be making this again and again.

Amazing tender and delicious! This recipe does not include potatoes or carrots which allows for a wonderful gravy which results in an extremely moist roast. All the moisture remains in the meat.

Added water to cover bottom of slow cooker pot and cooked a 2 lb. roast on high for 5 hours (without first searing). Roast turned out very tender and tasty and produced enough broth to make onion gravy. For a side dish, halved and broiled red and yellow baby potatoes and baby carrots all seasoned with Penzey's California pepper and Kosher salt. Husband loved meal.

I can't believe this worked! I have always used some sort of liquid - broth or wine. But, I followed the directions to the letter. I had plenty of juice, and chose not to make gravy out of it. We just used it as is over mashed potatoes, and had roasted broccoli (from this site). How delicious, and it is definitely a keeper!!

yum made this tonight, didn't have any bay leaves in the house so I added dried thyme leaves instead. I also threw in some baby carrots in with the onions at the beginning, great addition to the gravy at the end. will make this again for sure

OMG ... this is the BEST Pot Roast recipe!!!! I’ve made a lot of bad Pot Roasts in my day, but this came out awesome. Mine always came out DRY, but not this recipe. Thank you so much for sharing. This is a keeper !!!!!
I make this all the time. It is fantastic. I followed the recipe exactly and it was moist and sooooo flavorful. The gravy was out of this world!

I followed the recipe, mostly. I tweaked a few things. Before I brown my roast, I first cover it on both sides with some seasoned meat tenderizer. I let that sit for about 30 minutes, then sprinkle with granulated garlic, black pepper and a.p. Flour. I then take a small ceramic plate and pound the roast on both sides. I also added a cup of beef broth to the pan before going into the oven. This was the most delicious pot roast I’ve ever made!
It was Amazing!! I usually do my roasts in the crock pot but no more!! My kids loved it!!

Simple, quick and delicious. I skipped the artificial gravy and instead poured a cup of beef broth in the bottom of the roasting pan. Next time I will add some red wine for a little tang. Prep tweaks: Cut the roast into multiple sections, Salt and Pepper all sides, then sear it well. I added 6 carrots and 6 red potatoes, with salt and pepper, as sides - all in the roasting pan. Celery would be another option. Make sure you seal the pan well with aluminum foil so everything turns out moist. Best roast recipe I've made yet!

So yummy!! I seasoned the meat with salt, pepper and garlic powder (instead of the fresh minced garlic). I seared the meat with the onions and then, after I seared all sides, I did a rough chop of some carrots (in biggish chunks), layered them on the bottom with the bay leaf and then put the roast on top. All of the juices cooked into the carrots. SO GOOD! My husband asked to keep this as the 'go-to' roast recipe. So so delicious! I did extend the recipe a little by making gravy with the following gluten free recipe: After taking out the roast to rest on a platter, I add 1 tsp. Xanthan Gum to the leftover beef au jus, whisk well. Add 1 c. water and then a beef bouillon cube (or granules), bring to just to a boil and then spoon over your roast!

I just made this, and for someone who doesn't usually eat pot roast I actually like it! The only things I did differently was add this Chupacabra Rub before I seared it because I was in a rush and didn't read reviews until after I did. I also added chopped carrots and celery with the onions. My chuck roast was a little less than 5 lbs. I used a 2 piece lodge cast iron combo cooker (3.2 quart) together it's like a Dutch oven. I had plenty of juices left over, I want to say around 2 cups? The meat was tender after the last 1.5 hours. I served it with sautéed asparagus and steamed potatoes ( in the Instant pot). This recipe is a keeper!
I do this about once a month. I however seater
My previous roast came out so dry it sucked part of my soul out. This one came out perfectly. Because it was smaller (3 lbs) I cooked it for 1 hour at 300 instead of 1.5 hours.

I followed the recipe except my roast was smaller 2.5 lbs so I lowered the cooking temp. I did 15 minutes at 300 and then lowered to 275 for 1.5 hours. I should have checked it after one hour because it was cooked a little to well done for our taste but it was very tender. I will make this again and use a bigger roast or less cook time. Great recipe.
No changes. Great just as it is. My family ate it all. Will make again.
Made as originally described. Roast Was very flavorfull. Would use this recipe again for easy roast. Very good

I made this exactly as the recipe calls. The only thing I changed was the cookie my vessel - since I don't have a Dutch oven, I used a cast iron frying pan and covered the roast in foil to cook. The roast turned out perfect. The delicious flavour of the beef stands on its own and the onions, garlic, salt, pepper, and bay leaves finish it off perfectly. The meat was moist and delicious. My husband loved it and went back for seconds. I'm saving this recipe into my favourites box. Thank you for posting it Teresa!

Easy to make, with yummy results - would definitely make again! I opted to pre-season from the day before (made a "rub" by blending garlic, onions, escallions, and adding salt, pepper and Worcestershire sauce)...so tender and delicious!
Made it as directed. No additions! Very tasty!
